Literature Review: The field of DNA repair has been pivotal in our understanding of genomic stability, mutagenesis, and cancer development. This literature review focuses on endogenous DNA damage, base excision repair (BER), and their implications for cancer-causing mutations, as highlighted in the autobiographical reflections of a prominent researcher in the field. Endogenous DNA damage is a constant threat to genomic integrity, occurring spontaneously due to various cellular processes. One of the most common forms of such damage is the loss of purine bases, a process known as depurination. Lindahl and Nyberg (1972) estimated that approximately 10,000 purine bases are lost from the DNA of each human cell every day under physiological conditions. This finding underscored the importance of understanding DNA repair mechanisms to maintain genomic stability. Another significant form of endogenous DNA damage is cytosine deamination, which results in the conversion of cytosine to uracil. Lindahl and Nyberg (1974) demonstrated that this process occurs at a rate of about 100 events per cell per day. The presence of uracil in DNA, if left unrepaired, can lead to C:G to T:A transition mutations, which are frequently observed in cancer cells. The discovery of these endogenous DNA alterations led to the identification and characterization of the base excision repair (BER) pathway. BER is a highly conserved DNA repair mechanism that addresses a wide range of DNA base lesions, including those resulting from oxidation, alkylation, and deamination (Krokan and Bjørås, 2013). The pathway involves multiple steps, including lesion recognition, base excision, strand incision, gap filling, and ligation. DNA glycosylases play a crucial role in initiating the BER pathway by recognizing and removing damaged bases. Lindahl (1974) first discovered uracil-DNA glycosylase, which specifically removes uracil from DNA. This discovery paved the way for the identification of numerous other DNA glycosylases, each with specific substrate preferences (Jacobs and Schär, 2012). The importance of BER in maintaining genomic stability is further emphasized by its role in preventing cancer-causing mutations. Mutations in BER genes have been associated with increased cancer susceptibility. For instance, MUTYH-associated polyposis, an autosomal recessive colorectal adenoma and carcinoma predisposition syndrome, is caused by biallelic mutations in the MUTYH gene, which encodes a DNA glycosylase involved in repairing oxidative DNA damage (Al-Tassan et al., 2002). While BER is a primary mechanism for addressing endogenous DNA damage, alternative repair strategies have evolved to handle some unusual DNA lesions. For example, the direct reversal of O6-methylguanine by O6-methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) provides a rapid and efficient means of repairing this highly mutagenic lesion without the need for base excision or strand breakage (Pegg, 2011). The proposal that endogenous DNA damage is a major source of cancer-causing mutations has gained significant support over the years. Tomasetti et al. (2017) provided evidence that approximately two-thirds of mutations in human cancers are attributable to DNA replication errors, which are often a consequence of endogenous processes. This finding highlights the critical role of DNA repair mechanisms, particularly BER, in preventing cancer development. Recent advances in sequencing technologies have allowed for a more comprehensive understanding of the mutational landscapes in cancer genomes. Alexandrov et al. (2013) identified distinct mutational signatures in cancer, some of which are associated with deficiencies in DNA repair pathways. These findings further underscore the importance of DNA repair in cancer prevention and provide new avenues for targeted therapies. The autobiographical nature of the article in question adds a unique perspective to the field, offering insights into the personal journey and scientific discoveries that have shaped our understanding of DNA fragility and repair. Such reflections are valuable not only for their historical significance but also for inspiring future generations of researchers in the field. In conclusion, the study of endogenous DNA damage and repair mechanisms, particularly the base excision repair pathway, has been instrumental in our understanding of genomic stability and cancer development. The recognition of endogenous DNA alterations as a major source of cancer-causing mutations emphasizes the critical role of DNA repair in maintaining cellular health and preventing disease. As our knowledge of these processes continues to expand, new opportunities for cancer prevention and treatment are likely to emerge.
